31st October 2009Post Borefts I Invasion of Fonefan and Charlottes room tasting! Hazy gold beer, frothy white head. Softish palate. Smooth creamy tripel. Plenty of sweetish aromatic malt. Finishes minerally and crisp. A really nice tripel. Light and tasty and memorable. One of the best.

Form the State Liquor Store in Salt Lake City, UT courtesy of my brother Rick.  Poured a gold color with a foam beige head and lots of lacing rings. Nose of caramel malts, light flavorful fruits, and floral hops. Medium bodied with a smooth creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is a mixture of things, with a hint of clove on top of what is mostly fruit. A little funk in the finish. Good ale.

Active slightly hazed golden amber with a quickly fading tan head.  Aroma of coriander, fruit, yeast, orange and toasted malt.  Taste is fruity with toasted malt, yeast, bready malt, alcohol and white pepper.  Over-carbonated with a noticeable burn on the finish.

750ml bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a hazy dark gold with about 2 fingers of thick white head. Aroma of fruity yeast and a little spicy hops. Taste is medium sweet. Banana, fruity yeast and spicy hops. Medium bodied with a creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long boozy finish. Overall, very good. I would gladly drink this one again.

Pouts hazy orange. Tall white long lasting head. Nose is very fruity, peach and orange. Taste is complex mix of sour and sweet. Good tripel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very pleasant yeast heavy with traces of citrus fruits. slight sweetnes in arma. dark gold light amber in color with ample head. head subsides to one finger quick enough. Taste is nice and malty with noticeable spice.  No booze to be found in this creamy mouthfeel.  Nice.
Deep gold, white head.  Nice rich aroma, some banana, clove, double bubble, yeast, doughy malts.  Flavor is sweet up front, banana, yeasty, bready, spice cake.  Good!

Cloudy orange gold with a fluffy white head. Yeast and banana nose. Layered, full bodied palate with some apple and pear, hint of banana and some sage and clove. Highly Effervesscent with a clean mouthfeel. Long finish.

Pours golden orange with a sudsy white head. Smells spicy and malted and fruity. Taste is a bit bready, fruity, and sweet with spices. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and average mouth-carbonation, Boulevard Long Strange Tripel finishes with a hint of spiciness and bitterness.

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours copper with a thick, off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, spicy yeast, and some floral hops.  A pretty good tripel.  Average texture.  Standard for the style, definitely worth buying.

750ml bottle. Pours golden orange with a foamy off-white head. Aroma is of spice, banana, malt, yeast, and grain. Taste is of yeast, banana, malt, and some grain. Has a lot of spice, which lingers on after each sip. The alcohol is ever present in each sip. Very malty as well. Its a good beer, and it gets you drunk. Easy to drink.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Spicy, sweet, big alcohol kick as is common with the style.  Good complexity of flavor.  Boulevard does such a good job with many styles; their tripel is no exception.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2015 Beautiful hazy-gold pour, nice white head. Not my favorite trip. Wonderful sweet aroma of bananas and yeast, flavor of bananas, cloves, and Belgian yeast. Sweet finish, medium-high carbonation.

750ml corked bottle pours a slightly hazy golden color with a 2 finger white creamy head that leaves some thin lacing on the glass.  Aroma is light fruits with yeast and some mild hops.  Taste is modest malty sweetness with some fruits and yeast and a mild hop bitterness.  Light to medium body with some generous carbonation.  A pleasant tasting Belgian style tripel that I rather enjoyed sampling.

Pint bottle w/ cork. Aroma: Yeasty, fruity scent with notes of spice, slight floral, malty. Appearance: Golden yellow with white, creamy, lasting head. Taste: Strong taste of alcohol up front with good, lasting bitterness, medium body but fairly complex. Palate: Medium body, slick texture, fizzy carbonation, long, astringent and somewhat sweet finish. A deceptively heavy beer with complex flavor and strong alcohol/bitter notes to accompany fruity sweetness.

Pours a deep dark gold with nice white head.  Sticky with some nice lacing and spider legs. Aroma is malty and fruity. Quite pleasant.   Flavor offers a full chorus of the expected flavors.  Wonderful.

Location: 750 ml bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 3/12/12


Aroma: The nose has a lot of spice and yeast, with some fruity lemon and malty notes

Appearance: It pours a bright golden color, bubbly, and with a big, foamy, white head

Flavor: The taste is medium-plus sweet, with some peppery spices and minimal bitterness

Palate: The body is medium, it has a little bit of heat, and a lasting tingle on the mouth

Overall Impression: 
I thought this was a decent beer.  The spice and the sweetness work pretty decently together, but I would have liked a little bitterness for some balance.  Its still pretty good, but I have to deduct just a touch from the taste for that lack of balance.

It has the appearance of orange juice with a small white head.  The aroma is sweet, light fruit and floral.  It has a medium body with a smooth texture and average carbonation.  The taste is sweet, but there is a slight alcohol warmth lurking underneath.

Pours gold-orange with soapy white head that leaves little lacing. Aroma is fairly light with some citrus and other aromas I cant quite place. Flavor is similarly hard for me to place but is rather nice, refreshing, with hints of citrus and spice.

Confusing beer to rate.  Most aspects are good.  Valiant effort for an american trying to do an accurate version of the style.  But the strong flavour of very ripe orange and clementine with a strongish vinous vein and a dead yeast aftertaste make me want to lower the overall score.  The body and smell are alive.  Clean cool anise, light pepper, citrus,  fresh grain nose.  Flavor is very sweet light malt biscuit, heavy lively yeast middle, and too much cloying yeast and over ripe orange with some apple and peach.  Body is thick, slick, n lively.  Alcohol is not so hidden despite this very flavorful beer.

Shared with Holy.  Cloudy golden orange, head dissapeared quickly.  Light citrus aroma.  Flavor starts with a bit of malt and fades to a light orange, finishing with an orange peel dryness.  Good, but not very complex.
Bottle shared with quiznoaz. Citrus, orange. One huge difference between this and other tripels, this one has a bearded dudes picture on the label.

Appearance: cloudy oranges  on the darker side. Bready head fades into a nice collar bordering a tempting blotchy head. Swirls bready with tiny bubbles.

Nose: orange zest and spice. Green bananas. Burlap sacks and baled hay. Raw unadulterated skins-included guava, star fruit, and coconut. Ginger and cumin. Yeasty and estery.

Palate: light airy mouthfeel. Very dry finish  parching and thirst inducing  with coconut husk, straw, guava, and green banana skin. Honeyed yeasty doughy spicy bakers delight. Cumin and ginger. Dusty hay finish.

Final Thoughts: another winner from Boulevard Brewing. A solid line of every day beers complimented by a solid line of specialty beers as diverse and inspired as the human mind itself.

Golden with a frothy white cloud of foam resting atop this hometown beauty. Sweet, floral and yeasty aroma.  The flavor is about the same but a touch more specific with peach, sugar, stone fruit and earth.  A great value.

Hazy orange pour with long lasting off-white head. Banana, clove and hints of anise and other spices in the aroma. Heavy clove flavor at the outset with banana, lemon and some spiciness present. This transitions to  somewhat dry finish with a nice lingering alcohol warmth. Very tasty stuff...
Pours hazy gold with a white head.  Aroma of clove, banana, Belgian yeast.  Good flavor, very sweet.  Good tripel though.

Poured from bottle into a chalice. Pours a solid and hazy yellow/orange color with a small head

excellent and complex aromas of orange peels, spices, florals and some apricots as well

full bodied with a real creamy feel to it. Smooth and polished with excellent flavors of oranges peels, spices and some florals

this is an extremely good tripel. Has the right feel and flavors to go with it
Pours golden with a huge head. Strong applelike aroma. Flavors of citrus and clove. Some honey sweetness as well. Very full mouthfeel with some alcohol burn to it on the finish.

750 ml into my Boulevard tulip glass. Pours a beautiful hazy orange with a big fluffy pure white head. The appearance of this beer is breath taking. Aromas of coriander, black pepper, citrus and a nice Belgian yeast. Flavors are clean and well balance. Dry and very drinkable. A fantastic representation of a classic tripel.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 Large corked bottle. Slightly hazy golden orange pour with a nice lingering head. Citrus, clove, banana and pepper. Very good tripel. Boulevard has become a new favorite of mine.

Pours a slightly cloudy orange color with a finger of white head.  Aromas of banana and clove are prominent.  There is also quite a bit of bread and maybe some straw and yeast.  The flavor also has strong banana notes as well as straw, yeast, bread, pear, and light clove.

Bottle. Poured a hazy orange color with a decent white head that did retain throughout the entire beer. Aroma was lemony, grass and citrus. Flavor was citrusy, with bread, some pepper, and lemon flavors. Left a lot of floaters. Good decent beer, not the best Boulevard but still very good.

Cloudy, yellow copper pour with white pillowy head.  Aromas of bananas and hay.  Taste is little sweet, light bitterness, very little alcohol taste, and spices.  Palate is lively carbonation with some creaminess.  Overall, nice brew, true to style, and good flavor.

Clear and slightly dark yellow color. Nose of clove, a bit of raisin and really not much else. Taste of coriander, caramel, grains of paradise, and light alcohol. Finish is exceeding spicy. Wanted to like this more than I did but eh, its made in America.
Corked bottle. Golden color. Peach and pineapple in the aroma. Tropical fruit and some grassy, earthy hops in the slightly alcoholic flavor. Hints of cedar and oak. Well crafted tripel.
Bread, yeast and spices in the aroma.  The flavor is yeasty and slightly effervescent with a spicy and fruity edge to it.  Very, very good tripel, among the best American versions.

The pour is a hazy, golden color with an average, white, fluffy head which settles to nearly nothing and leaves minimal lace rings.  The nose is sweet and fruit, even for a tripel; lots if candi sugar, blood orange, alcohol wisps, dry herbs (tarragon), maybe some cardamom.  The flavor is similar with plenty of light candi sugar, still very orangey, cardamom, estery yeast notes, and lighter alcohol and similar herbs.  The palate is lively, more than medium, creamy, and just slightly drying.  The beer finishes mostly sweet and yeasty, still candi sugar, some alcohol, and slight herbal presence.  Very much like a Delirium beer with more candi sugar than anything, but still pleasant to drink.  The alcohol had a prominent role which did add depth and complexity.  Good tripel but not one of my style.

(750ml bottle) clear yellow with a ring of fine white bubbles. Nose of clove, a bit of raisin and really not much else. Taste of coriander, caramel, grains of paradise, and light alcohol. Finish is exceeding spicy. Wanted to like this more than I did.
A huge head at first. This has got a spicy aroma. A pretty tasty beer with plenty of spice. The only downside is that my bottle tastes a bit flat.

A very solid beer for an American brewer. Its no Belgium, but it was an interesting beer that I rather enjoyed. Just popped the second bottle, and while I liked it better fresh it was still very good with about a year on it.
Pours gold into a snifter. White head with good retention recedes leaving no lacing. Dusty lemon and yeast aromas. Crisp and sweet with upfront caramel and a lasting dry lemony yeast finish.

750ml bottle from Belmont Station. Pours dirty blonde with a decent apricot head and a fruity aroma .There is a very carbonated peach and banana flavor with a heavy yeast presence and a sharp peppery finish.

Bomber. Poured gold with a yellowish hue. Aroma was sweet citrus, some off fruit notes as well. Classic belgian yeasty aroma as well. Slight alcohol undertow noted. A good buy if you see one in your store.

Slightly hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is very yeasty. Cloves, citrus, alcohol, bubblegum and bready pale malt. Sharp, spicy taste. Very malty and yeasty with bit of hop bitterness and a slight warming alcohol presence. Full bodied and a little fizzy and dry.

. Foamy lacy big white head.S lightly cloudy orange gold color. Hop and Belgian fruit ester floral front. 
Beer haad a zestiness to it.  mild spices  seem to be a n understated tripel to me ath that is a good thing; dry finish.  need to try again..

Bottle. Pour is golden with a very good white head which leaves a good retention. Aroma is fruity belgo yeast, banana, lots of citrus, bread. Flavor is very sweet, bready, fruit, a bit of spice. Palate is soft, light, and very clean. Excellent tripel.
Opaque golden yellow color. Nice white head with good lacing. hints of creamy apricot and bananas. Solid, has some age, could have been a lot bigger had it been fresh.

Hefiger Geruch. Hefig-süßer Antrunk, mittelhopfig, etwas stärker werdend. Im Mittelteil etwas alkoholisch, nur leicht malzig, ausbalanciert. 	 
Test vom 10.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: -,12,11,10,12,11 - 11,05

Bottle @ home. Moderately cloudy, a touch dark orange appearance with a fairly sizable carbonated tan head. Yeasty, orange citrusy, floral belgian ale nose. Floral, citrusy, moderately yeasty, pale malty flavor with a dry floral finish. Citrus floral aftertaste. Alcohol is hidden pretty well.
Slightly hazy orange, large beige head. Aroma of banana, caramel, peach, gum. Taste has a little bit of tart to it, lots of sweet bready malt, mildly bittern finish.

Cloudy orange with big, flotsam, quickly dissapating, white head / Nose of orchard fruit, spice, and musty brett / Medium body, creamy but tart and acidic, some cloying sweetness, with good balance and modestly bitter finish / Flavors of apple, apricot, orange zest, clove, coriander, must, and orchard rot / The clove, orange, and sugar are a touch overbearing, but its a fine tripel nonetheless.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2014 Very attractive hazy golden color and a thick off white head.  The aroma is wonderful, with hints of pineapple, banana, and peach, as well as malt.  The flavor is also fruity and is dominated by the belgian yeast, lots of banana and spice.

Pours a a nice golden yellow with a frothy wire head.  Nose is very Belgian with yeast, and grain.  Taste is nice and clean with yeast and a caramel sweetness.  I really enjoyed this more than I expected.

(750ml bottle courtesy of jrorie!!).  Pours a hazy apricot color with quick dissipating head.  Lots of carbonation.  Aroma has candied sugar and dried fruit.  Taste is sweet with a bit our sour.  Bitterness is very low and reminds me of citrus peel.  Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Finish is smooth with the alcohol noticeable mostly because it warms the throat and chest.  The sweetness is a tad to the high side, but its a pretty nice beer.  Id drink this again with pleasure.

750ml bottle.
Hazy golden pour with some fluffy white head.  Citrus, spice, clove, and honey aromas - flavors of banana, more clove and spices, and a bit of peach.  Not a bad Tripel but I was hoping for more.
750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a nice fluffy biege head.  Aroma of yeast, malt, spices and fruit.  Taste is somewhat sweet malt, yeast and fruit.  Very nice!

Bottle pours orange-yellow with huge white head.  Aroma citrus and light fruits.  Taste light fruits, orange, spices, peach, bread.  Palate full and quite carbonated.  Finish tangy and slight bitterness.  This is one of those beers whee the bitterness appears and then disappears before it becomes overpowering.  Alcohol apparent.  Good tripel.

Served in a tulip. Thanks to my father-in-law for picking up this bottle.

Pours a dark golden color with almost no head. No head on a tripel--are you kidding me? Bad, bad, bad. No good. The nose is a bit of malt with some very light phenols. Taste has a bit of bread with light yeast character. Not impressed. Feel is light with low carbonation. Overall, not impressed. This is nowhere near a tripel, let alone a good one.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-27-2011

Head i sabundant and creamy; honey color. Orange marmelade and bubble gum aromas; off-dry. Nice balance between bitter/dry and sweet on the palate.  One of the best blends between the dry belgian tripels and sweet american tripels.

Bottle shared with friends.  Extremely high carbonation, but not quite a gusher.  Cloudy yellow orange.  Aroma of black pepper, wet hay, straw.  Taste has moderate bitterness and light pepper.  A bit plain.

Bottle; Pour is Light, slightly cloud golden with a fairly nice off white head that retains well - light spotty lacing into this snifter. Grassy nose with a heavy sugary note present - The flavor profile is quite fruity and sweet , but it is nearly off putting. This brew is quite smooth for the style, with a bit of creaminess from the head, which is indeed nice. Your Belgian yeast note and fruit esters are present here - But the body of this brew feels lacking, with this over abundance of peaches and candied sugars, with a one dimensional feel through the finish. A good attempt, to be sure.

Large Strange Triple had a strong white head. First smell reminds me of  lager beer rather than a triple, next flavors are citrus and cloves. The appearance is an orange haze, with good carbonation.  Taste is clearly alcoholic, there is also blends of hops and medium bodied malts. Finally LST presents a creamy sweet finish. This beer was well worth the price.

Bottle - Pours cloudy with a creamy off-white head. Smells pretty fruity, with honey, apricot, and light spice on the nose. Smells a lot like New Glaruss Imperial Saison. Tastes is spicy and fairly dry, with some light fruitiness, sharp heat, and honey sweetness on the finish. Too hot and really carbonated--the biting type of carbonation that doesnt allow all those subtle flavors to come through. Not too impressed by this one.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Whole Foods Austin.  It pours a hazy gold color with a decent, fluffy, white head.  The nose is sweet with honey and light fruit notes.  There is a little bit of yeast and some candy sugar as well.  The flavor comes across as a bit on the sweet side with honey, candy sugar, and simple malt notes.  The Belgian yeast is there with a touch of peach but its underrepresented. Medium bodied with above average carbonation leading to a short to medium, slightly sweet finish.  This one came across as slightly above average to me.

Sample at Tasting Panel #1. 750ml bottle. Poured a golden bronze with decent, taffy like off white head. Aroma was Belgian yeast, spice crisp orchard fruit. Flavour was slightly boozy but also spiced apple, citrus, yeast. Very decent for the style.

750mL bottle, pours hazy golden orange with a towering white head. Aroma of yeast, apple, light citrus and medium sweetness. Flavour of candied fruits, yeast, green apple with just the right amount of sweetness. Very well-balanced and just how I like my tripels.

750ml bottle. Clear golden orange with a thick, foamy, off white head that leaves some lace. Aroma of spices, musty yeast, sugar and some hay. The flavor is sweeter than the aroma would suggest, lots of malt and sugar with very light sour yeast and a touch of hop bitterness, absolutely no alcohol taste. Medium body with a mellow carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. Pretty good tripel, a bit sweet and carbonation is a bit low, but still very drinkable and smooth.

bottle.  Pours light peach orange color, with fluffy, fizzy white head.  Pours perfectly into trappist glass, looks like a great triple.  Sweet aroma of honeysuckle, soft fruit tones like peach, white grape, apricot, and light spices, subtle clove.  Flavor is actually pretty different from aroma, medium to full bodied, and actually pretty complex.  Malty, yeasty fruit tones turn into a carbonated, sweet, spiced bite, which turns to a sort of dryness with white grape, to a breadiness, to a long finish that ultimately leaves traces of peach, apricot.  Very nice interpretation of a triple, especially it being an american version, I was surprised how much I found in this.

Bottle: Pours a gold color with a small white head. The nose is estery with plenty of yeast and light wheat notes. Some big malt flavors in the mouthfeel and a thicker body than I like to see in a triple. Seems like the carbonation is a little lacking as well. Good nose, but a little dense.
hazy gold with a small white head.  honey and pale malt aroma.  white grape, apple,  spicy hops flavor.  palate is medium with a good bit of carbonation.  lightly astringent.  not my favorite

Incredibly hard to open 750ml. Hazy orange translucent appearance. Quite the fizzy head the seems to be dissipating into a thin and wispy head. It looks quite delicious, for it being a tripel and all. Dough, yeast, applesauce, fresh apples, cinnamon, and other spices seem to be coming through in the aroma. This beer has a wonderfully nuanced and pungent aroma. Its quite carbonated, but at the same time, it is rich as well.

Bottle at the Funky 6. Cloudy gold pour with an off-white head. Heavy aroma, lots of fruit, malts, alcohol and caramel. Flavor is nice and sweet with spices, yeast, lightly toasted malts and subtle bitterness. Medium bodied with average to strong carbonation. Lightly warming, yeasty and fruity on the finish. Great stuff.

Bottle that I brought to Hamilton Creek "Pink finale" tasting. Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Nice citrusy and Belgian ester aroma. Medium bodied with an organic mouthfeel, and steady carbonation. Flavor of pale wheat malts, pear, nectarine, and clove. Yeasty finish with alcohol well hidden. This is the way I like my Tripels. Well done.

Bomber poured into shaker.    No hint of alcohol whatsoever in this smooth Tripel.   Wheaty and strong malt flavors with some citrus characteristics.   If new to Tripels, this is a good starting point.
color is golden, very cloudy. thick frothy white head. very malty aroma, bit of mustiness and lemon, too. hints of bubblegum and lemon in the flavor with just a bit of alcohol to boot.
Cloudy copper orange with a beautiful white head.  Hops and malt are well balanced and it has a smooth slightly bitter finish that lasts about 20 seconds.

Poured from 750ml bottle, pours a hazy orange with a long lasting frothy head,  aroma has a nice kick of citrus with fruit and a hint of spices, the flavor is nice and crisp and has a nice flavor of spices and fruit.  Pretty enjoyable brew.

750ml bottle, batch #9317, courtesy of drfabulous. thanks, jeff! pours a hazy orange with a thick, fluffy, bright white head and dense lacing. aroma is great, very fruity forward with notes of pear juice, red apple, and banana esters backed by sweet, belgian yeast, candi sugar, and subtle spice notes of cinnamon and clove with a hint of wheat grass. flavor is damn tasty as well with the fruity tartness of lemon zest and granny smith apples emerging atop sweet cider notes, spices, light cedar, and sweet, yeasty bread with a touch of dry grass on the finish. palate is medium bodied with bright carbonation and a definite alcohol presence late in the swallow. overall, a very well made tripel.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Hazy apricot with a decent sized, foamy, white head. Pretty good retention with a thin layer of lace left.

S - Tart apple, pear and orchard fruit are quite strong. A good level of spiciness as well. Touches of candi sugar and a hint of Belgian yeast. Sweet and spicy aromas mix, with the spiced aspect winning out.

T - Like the nose, a strong spicy flavor with clove, white pepper, and a touch of orange rind. Tart golden fruit also makes up a large portion of the flavor. Background of sweet candi sugar and a slight fruity sweetness. Hints of yeast. Alcohol is definitely present, but not overly strong.

M - Medium body and carbonation. A little too sticky/syrupy for my liking.

D - With the strong spice, slight alcohol, and syrupy body this isnt overly drinkable and one that I took my time with. That said I wouldnt mind having one a different day.

Notes: Not entirely sure what to think of this. The flavors were nice, but then I thought they got to be a little overwhelming. Strong on the spices but a slight sweetness in the background.

Batch T1009, best by 4/11.  Bottle from unclemike.  This pours a golden color with a big thick off-white head.  Nice head retention the whole way through.  Banana, pear, yeasty aroma, with flowers as well as some spice.  Smells good.  The flavor offers some tart lemons into the mix with cloves, banana, bubblegum, straw, and spice.  At 9% this packs a bit of a punch, and I cant say the alcohol is hidden, but despite that it still offers some refreshing qualities.  This is yet another beer from Boulevard that I really quite enjoy.  If they make a bad beer I havent yet tried it.

750ml btl. Pours a hazy orange with a huge frothy white head. Nice big fresh citrus aroma with maybe a hint of banana. Obvious foreground citrus with a nice belgian spicy finish. A nice candied almost carameled sweetness buried underneath that kind of rushes in as the spiciness ends and melds with the booze. A nice american tripel.
Golden inn color, fizzy white head, aroma with hint of fruit and yeast. Smooth, stong alcohol, finsh is somehat sweet

Nice and clean flavored Triple with solid Belgian yeast qualities melding with light citrus and an overall refreshing quality.  Not a life-changer, but a good beer nonetheless.

Thanks to Maltomeal for the bottle!

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Golden pour with a fizzy white head. Sweet and fruity aroma with light hints of yeast and spice. Very mild for a tripel. Flavor is mild and fruity with some yeast and spice notes. Decent tripel, just mild and run of the mill.

750ml bottle from the state store 
Appearance: Pours slightly hazy straw/yellow with a nice white head and nice lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Sweet malts, spices and citrus 
Taste: Sweet malts, bready, yeast, pepper and some sweet citrus in the finish 
Nice Tripel, easy drinkability.

750 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy golden color with ample floaties throughout and a large frothy off white head.  The aroma was bready malts, somewhat fruity, citrus favoring lemons, yeast with hints of Belgian sugar.  The flavor is moderately sweet, but quite dry.  Bready malts, fruity that shows a slight tart character at times, spicy, floral and herbal notes as well.  The alcohol does show at times.  Medium full body with more than enough carbonation.

750. Pours very hazy gold, thick white head. Nice aroma, spicy and fruity, some clove. Taste is nice as well. Fruity, lemons, banana, some spice as well, clove. Mouthfeel is like champagne, nice carbonation. Good stuff.
Clove and oranges.  The aroma reminds me, somehow, of orange scented dryer sheets.  Flavor is more like a less-sweet orange creamsicle.

Thanks to drfabulous for this 750ml bottle.
The beer was an opaque orange/amber color with a very frothy white head. Nice aroma, creamy mouthfeel and a sweet finish make this quite tasty.

750 ml. bottle from Full Throttle Bottles. Hazy orange translucent appearance. Quite the fizzy head the seems to be dissipating into a thin and wispy head. It looks quite delicious, for it being a tripel and all. Dough, yeast, applesauce, fresh apples, cinnamon, and other spices seem to be coming through in the aroma. This beer has a wonderfully nuanced and pungent aroma. Its quite carbonated, but at the same time, it is rich as well. Apples, yeast, and a spicy zing are dominating the flavor. Yeast and dough are coming through as well. Its quite the tripel. It kind be slightly boozy at times, but its greatness overrides that. Fairly excellent.

Great label, great name, and great brewery -good beer too.
The aroma was a little spices, yeast, sweetness.  The appearance was golden with a smaller white head.  The flavors are typical belgian sweetness, some notes of bitterness and fruity flavors.  All-around a good beer, definitely not surprised that its 9% considering its a trippel, but you certainly dont taste it all ... its hidden very well.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of Belgian yeast, fruit, and slight spice.  Poured orange/amber in color with a large, creamy, off-white head that greatly diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of Belgian yeast, slight cocoa, malt, fruit, banana, light bubblegum, slight coriander, and slight spice.  Medium body.  Tingly, gaseous, then slightly dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Belgian yeast, slight spice, fruit, and banana finish is heavily sweet and dry.  9%ABV is completely hidden throughout.
Bottled sample.  Shared with some Bud Light firends and was enjoyed by everybody.  Would have this again.

750 ml bottle from Starrs Market.  Pours a cloudy orange-gold color with a small bone white head.  Aroma of wheat, spices, caramel malts, sugar, apricot, banana, and just a little alcohol.  Flavor of caramel and pale malts, sugar, apricots, bananas, mild spices, corn syrup, and cream.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sticky mouthfeel.  Sweet and malty.  Really nice tripel.

Hazy golden large white head aroma grass yeasts pepper coriander spices. Flavor s grassy peppery yeasty bananna tripel without too much sweetness. Effervescent carbonation and a good grassy hoppy dry sweet yeasty finish.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a small off-white head. Has a spicy yeasty aroma. Sweetish malty spicy flavor with some hints of yeast. Has a sweetish malty spicy yeasty finish.

This bottled brew from a beer festival poured a small sized head of finely sized white colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a and a fair lacing. The aroma was candy and malty. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of candy caramel and malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

Big fluffy head over a cloudy gold. Flavor is really smooth, fluffy wheat and light malt with only slight alcohol flavor. Aroma is of grains a clean sweet sugars. Very dry palate. Bottle from Maryland Farms Wine and Spirits in Nashville.

Unfortunately poured into a plastic cup in a hotel after a marathon, so couldnt get a complete feel for this one.  Banana, clove, yeast, and pepper in the nose.  Initial caramel, yeast, spicy flavor, with long, warm, slightly bitter finish.  Very good beer, especially in this style.

Ive had this beer numerous times. but for some reason have never rated it. Its truly one of the better American attempts at a Tripel. Spice, pepper, yeasty wheaty goodness. Good beer. Ill drink it anytime. Clean but rich. Good beer.
Pours a lacing beige head with a slightly hazy. deep golden body.  Aromas of banana, clove, zest, and yeast.  Flavor is the same.  Finish is dry, lasting, and spiced.

Bottle thanks to Chad!Dark orange-amber, frothy paper-white head. Nose of allspice, dry wheat, refreshing lemon on deep scents, pepper, and plum. Super complex in fact, a lot more than just that. Flavor is very peppery, more allspice, hints of banana, and dry bitterness through the finish. Well carbonated with a firm body, this is superbly balanced, nothing overdone but a hoard of things going on, the spices here top notch. A friend and I spend 15 minutes discussing how the appreciation of a tripel requires amalgamation. If true, this is the ultimate example.

750ml Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Golden yellow in color, thick with haze nice head.  This had tons of lemon and other fruit flavors along with that metallic flavor these brews give off.  Very nice brew to style.
I am still amazed at how authentic some of these smokestack series beers are to their styles. Great beer!

Batch Number T9114
3/17/2010:  Boulevard Long Strange Tripel...  Aroma:  Lemony, yeasty, raw bread dough; distant fruitiness.  Appearance:  Golden color made nearly opaque by the amount of debris suspended in it; nearly volacanic carbonation; foamy, frothy, shimmering off-white head.  Flavor:  Sweet and malty; freshy fruits (soft pineapple and citrus pithe); spicy, sharp, and metallic mid-palate; strong, dry alcoholic finish; herbal hop bite in the finish.  Palate:  Medium to medium-full body; well-carbonated but not too much; Overall:  Decent, but not really my cup of tea.
1 pint, 9.4 fl. oz. bottle (9.0% ALC/VOL) shared by Tmoney99.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #272 for this beer.

The beer pours a hazy orange color with a large white head. The aroma is orange citrus with Belgian yeast, spices and some alcohol. The flavor is alcohol, citrus (oranges and pears) with some coriander, pepper and Belgian yeast. The alcohol is rather strong in the aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel and medium-high carbonation.

750ml Corked bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy dark gold with tiny particles floating throughout and an initially thick head which settles to a thin yet creamy film covering the top. Spicy aroma of pepper, hops and esters. Really smooth body with soft carbonation. Flavor is interesting. Buttery popcorn comes to mind as well as some light floral hops which are subtley bitter. Overall a very strange tripel indeed but enjoyable none the less.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Poured from bottle. Bright, floral nose. Pours a rich gold with head and lace. Very dry on the tongue; intense hops bitterness and a very clean carbonation and finish. Good, refreshing.

750 ml bottle likely from mreusch. Thanks, Matt! The next step on my Smokestack journey as we get closer to the end. Pours a murky golden orange, a bit darker but still glowing, a big frothy offwhite head that is looser bubblewise, laces a bit, stays decent sized. Aromas are a melange of fruity esters, apple and pear, lighter bananas, grainy bready malts, a light yeasty spice, vanilla and honey, light clove. A touch of orange. Initial is medium bodied, sweeter with sugary fruits, pear and apple, decent yeasty spice, bread, grainy cereal malts, vanilla, honey, light bitterness and potent prickly booziness. Sweeter, a touch of orange, banana, the dryness grows a bit, lingering booziness and bitterness sticks more over more sips. A bit floral, orange rind and sweet grainy malts, a touch of candi sugar, Belgian yeast. An interesting brew, dry yet sweet, good booziness and bitterness. Not bad, just generally not my thing.
Pours hazy orange with white head, aroma is clove, banana, bubblegum, spice, and coriander.  Taste is typical sweet wit, with some banana, clove, bubblegum, and a sweet finish.

Bottle.Pours a hazy golden orange with a frothy white head. Aroma was sweet and pale malts, honey, yeast and light fruit. Flavor was rich and creamy with honey, banana, citrus, yeast and some light spices.

Burnt Orange Pour with a frothy white head that leaps back up after a swirl.  ARoma is burnt sugars, spicy yeastiness, some light breadiness.  Light grassiness as well.  Flavor is rich, sugary, lightly burnt, some bread, boozy with a flutter of grassy sweetness.  Rich layers of boozey, yeasty, bready, sweet malt.  Really tasty, very good looking treat from boulevard

Bottle @ Papsø. Thanks. Pours unclear golden with a small creamy egg white head. Nose is vaguely oxidized and has notes of fruit and yeast. Flavor is very fruity with mild yeast and again some oxidation. Full bodied.

75 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild caramelish and malty. Sweet and roasted malt flavoured. Light phenolic and subdued spiced touch from back of the tongue. Dry and malty into the far finish.
Bottle at Papsø 23-Apr-2010 - Thanks. Cloudy golden - white head. Lovely fruity, light sweetness, fullbodied, light flowery, licorice, hay niotes, grape notes, light yeasty. Nice.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma of yeast, citrus, fruits and light sweetness. Flavour of alcohol, spice, yeast and fruits. Meidum bodied. Dry grapy fruityness in the end.

bottle at papsoe unclear yellow with floaties, thick creamy offwhite head.
nice belgian style spicy yellow fruity aroma. also some sweetness (berries or banana)
flavor is yellow fruity, spicy, dry. strong. really tastes like a belgian.

Tasting at PapsøHazy golden color; generous head. Light aroma, some malt, some fruits from the fermentation, very light vegetables. Malt flavor, sweetish, with a light vegetables presence; the bitterness is not too high, but the alcohol can be perceived. Not bad, but another failed American attempt in brewing a Belgian beer. Overall, just a sweetish Belgian Strong.

Boulevard 75 cl. Pours a hazy golden with an off-white head. Intensely fruity nose - sweet and alcoholic. Solid body, sweet overripe fruit, not overly yeasty but on the edge of oxidization. No real bitterness but a warming alcohol finish. Quite delicious. 230410

orange pour with a thick tight white head.
aroma is yeasty fruity tones dominating.  apple, apricot, pear, some biscuity maltiness coming through. Some spicy hop in the finish.
Flavour is again more fruit, apple and dried apricot. nice sweet bready malt, some caramel. A touch of alc. heat towards the end. 
very nice.

Very nice tripel. Rich golden, thick frothy head, cloudy and glowing. Aroma is wonderful banana and apple esters, yeasty, bready, caramel, hints of roasty malt, allspice and cloves. Tastes like an effervescent, granny smith, spiced desert with bready, sweet and sticky quality that fills the mouth. By fluke it paired extremely well with the maple compote-style desert that our friends picked-out.

Poured a hazy copper color with a short white head.  The aroma was malts, banana, spice, yeast esters.  The flavor was fruit, yeast and spice.  Very tasty.  The mouthfeel was almost oily or slick at times.  Overall it was quite good.

Bottle. Poured a hazy orange color with a large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate to heavy citrus, yeast and small alcohol aroma. Medium body with a smooth sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid complex brew.

Had in bottle.  Pours hazy golden color with bits of sediment and a finger thick white head.  Flavor is fruity and very carbonated.  Impressive brew, good tripel.  More than I expected from Boulevard.

Maybe I just wasnt in the mood for this but I really didnt enjoy much.  I cant say it was bad but the Tripel is definetly a different beer style.  I have had several of the other Smokestack series and enjoyed them all very well - just dont know on this one right now.

Pours a lovely hazy golden color with a an ample white fizzy head. Aroma is of citrus, with some light bread and fruit notes peaking through. Taste is crisp and refreshing with a pronounced citrus taste, but with the classic fruit/bread notes of a Belgian Tripel. By far this is the best U.S. Tripel that I have ever had, and usually I am not a huge Tripel fan to begin with, but this is worth buying a few more bottles.

750ml bottle from Argonaut Liquors in Denver.  I bought this during GABF and just got around to opening it.  Shared it with my cousins, aunt, and uncle, who are some what of beer newbies, as my uncles beer of choice is PBR and the others beers of choice are wine.  I was worried this one would be mediocre, but it did not disappoint.  Pours clear golden with a large, lacey white head that lasts a long time.  Aroma is very good and true to style: sweet malt, honey, green apple and citrus, and Belgian yeast.  Flavor is also great, a little sweet and well-balanced.  Lots of light fruits (green apple, pear, apricot, and citrus), with sweet pale malt and honey, spices, and Belgian yeast.  Medium-bodied with average carbonation and a satisfying mouthfeel.  Extremely drinkable for the 9% ABV.  A really well-crafted beer overall, one of the better American examples of this style that Ive had.

11/28/08 6pm .. . batch T8172 .. . red team go, red team go .. honey, and other typical aromas .. . good white sturdy head .. . quite dry, lots of bitterness .. . some fruit, honey, very light spices .. bolder than most .. but still like a mean kitten .. . only a hit of acid would make this tripel better.. . who put all this cotton in my mouth??

Tasted long, long ago when the Smokestack line was first released, prior to my Ratebeer membership!

750mL bottle pours a cloudy, glowing orange with a big rocky head that fights dissipating for quite a while and laces in big drips.  Sweet, fruity aroma smacks of green apple and belgian yeast.  Flavor follows suit, with a strong malt backbone highlighted by very acidic green fruits and chewy bread yeast.

Strong, strong carbonation blasts the aroma out of the glass and the flavor across the tongue, but makes this a less-than-sessionable brew.

Batch #T8123
Pours clear dark yellow with a fleeting white head.
Very subdued aroma, malt some perfume from the yeast.  Not bad aroma, just very little of it.
Lightly sweet.  Maybe this has faded away.  
Light bodied as it should be and very easy to drink.  Could use more complexity.

This would be my Kansas tick according to a member of the Richmond crew who shall not be named. ;) C&C 750 mL bottle courtesy of riversideAK. Thanks! Thanks also to STLWill who also sent me a bottle. Pours a clear orange color with a large cream colored head. Decent head retention and lacing. Lots of visible carbonation. Aroma of bread, caramel, apricots, citrus, coconut, faint nutty notes. Taste is bread, caramel, coconut, peach, pear and other stone fruits, citrusy finish. Medium bodied and fairly strong carbonation. Good, tasty beer.

A huge golden head erupts during the pour.  It is noisy but lasts a good while.  The beer is cloudy, well carbonated, and a dark golden color.  Nose is mostly banana but other fruit.  Flavor is also banana, apple, alcohol.  Finish is a bit buttery.  A nice beer but I expected more.

pours golden, white head
aroma, mostly yeasty nose with some malty and wheat notes.
flavor, Belgian yeast, some fruits; banana, wheat, nice thick fruit palate, lasting grainy palate, doughy and malty finish. Highly refreshing at 9% and right balance between the yeast the the fresh fruit flavor that compliment the overall profile.

Bottle:  Pours a golden wheat color with a large, fluffy, sand colored head.  Initial impression from the aroma is very fruity.  Apples and pears.  Followed by a light amount of yeast and very light spiciness.  At first sip I am taken back by the intense amount of carbonation here... very bubbly.  More fruity flavors of apples, pears, and grapes.  Again light yeast and light spiciness.  The alcohol becomes a bit brash in the tail and detracts from the overall experience.  The sweetness of the brew tries to cover it up, but doesnt quite get there.  Still a nice trip.

(bottle, sampled 1/29/10). Cloudy orange color, with particles suspended. Medium off white head. Aroma of fruit and light dough. Dough flavor with light alcohol. Avg duration. Moderate alcohol finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

750ml corked and caged bottle.  Hazy orange-tan color with a massive, foamy head.  Sweet earthy candi-sugar aroma.  Certainly comes closer than most US versions in creating a Belgian-like body.  Perhaps a touch sweeter than your typical Tripel, this is a full and rugged 9% beer.  Rich and creamy on the palate.  This is really an ass-kicker of a beer, probably best split up with friends or family.  Another winner from the Smokestack series.
750ml. Hazed yellow/orange with medium white head. Aroma is spice, citrus fruits and yeast. Flavor is similar but more fruity sweetish. Interesting brew with sweet finish with little bite.
Bottle at Borefts 10am day after hotel tasting after a very bad drunk Borefts festival ... amber ... sweet yeasty nose ... bright fruit hop ... yeast ... sweet

Long Strange Tripel--Bottle Conditioned Ale-No. 3 in the Boulevard Smokestack Series 2009 Release--25.4 oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV.  30 IBUs.  4.0 / 5.0 Rating.  Belgian Ale--Tripel.  Foamy lacy big white head.Bright slightly cloudy orange gold color.  Mild hop rich Belgian fruit ester floral front.  Zesty fizzy mild sweet crisp dry fruit ester rich Belgian mild banana body.  Mild hop tangy spicy Belgian sweet dry end.  Refreshing.No sediment.  Sampled 5/17/2009.  $8.99 Each

Great effort at a Belgian style tripel! Poured  a large foamy frothy white head and a load of lace. Aroma is subdued. Flavors spot on. Has that Belgian vineous character. The Belgian version might be a tab more dry and crisp. This one has plenty of body and a hair less carbonated. Feel the booze. Tasty.

Bottle: &nbsp Dark straw, cloudy, moderate frothy off-white head, sparce lacing. &nbsp Heavy floral nose, to the point that it is bready. &nbsp Warm, alcohol, seems hefty. &nbsp Strong bready floralness. &nbsp Heavy, much moreso than most. &nbsp Typical American example. &nbsp Not as floral or spritzy as Belgian examples. &nbsp Pretty much what I expected. &nbsp A bit heavier than most, but like so many American examples it is more bready than floral. &nbsp Decent example, pretty much what I expected.

Thaks to JDskinns for this bottle. Pours out a somewhat clear, slightly hazy golden color with a lively white head: well carbonated. Aroma is of some light spice, bananna, fruit and some yeast notess. Taste is complex some notes of bananna, light clove, slight notes of soem other spice make an appearance, also some sweet fruity notes combined with a yeasty note here and there. Rather well balanced between sweet and dry. Well done.

Still learning to appreciate this style and this one was pretty good.  Orange with a light tan head.  It had a lot of spice flavor - maybe little much for me.  Im sure Im rating it less than most and thats because I dont like the style as much as others do.

750 ml bottle shared by Pineypower, thanks Dean. Pours a nice orange/amber with an average to large sized white foamy head. Aroma is sweet with notes of candi sugar, tropical fruit, yeast, alcohol, over ripe banana peels and grains. Body is a little thin with average to strong carbonation and despite the addition of suagr this one isnt to sweet and is borderline dry. Flavor of sugar, tropical fruit, yeast, grain and alcohol. Really well done and despite my distaste for drier beers this one is actually balanced nicely between sweet and dry.

Pours a murky golden color with slight orange hues.  Aroma of Sourdough bread, alcohol and citrus.  Flavor is sweet with hints of grain and yeast.  Finish is slightly sour while maintaining similar taste.

750mL bottle, Batch T7276 (I think this was the first bottled batch, but could be mistaken).  Poured crisp medium orange with a short, dense cap of white head.  The aroma picked up warm toasted pale malts, honey, and mild sourdough bread.. the latter element quite smoothly rolled into a touch of lemon zest and coriander spicage.. dusty yeast and mild-to-moderate warmth surrounded.. very well done!  The flavor found honey (darker grade) and sourdough again at the core with white pepper, coriander, and lemon zest around.. as it warmed up, the alcohol presence intensified and played well with the dusty yeast and spices.. memorable spice array on the finish.  Medium-plus bodied with tight, rolling carbonation on the palate.. maybe a touch too sweet overall, but it still felt and tasted great!

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2009 Deep color, creamy smooth head. Good strong aroma. Flavor has a nice mild spice. Very enjoyable. First pour has almost no sediment, but I see a ton of sediment still in the bottle. Second pour, swirling to mix the sediment: most all the sediment "dissolved" and flavor still very nice--maybe even a little smoother. Nice!

750 ml bottle. Pours a hazy glowing orange with plenty of sediment and a thick pillowy white head. Aroma is very floral and spicy with a big presence of pear and apple, lots of esters and pretty straight forward. Flavor starts with an immediately pepper and floral honey character. Quickly mellows and gets a sweet banana yeast and more light fruitiness. Some alcohol becomes apparent towards the finish but stays smooth in the aftertaste. Medium bodied and prickly carbonation. Well done trippel, very quaffable.

Bottle my folks got me at a shop in Dallas, and since there doesnt seem to be any more beer here this is what Im drinking.  Pretty good and surprising since I know Ive seen it in SD.  Pours orange big tan head nose is sweet taste is sweet vinous and quite good, gotta say this is a good tripel better than most domestic ones.

Bottle at post Borefts BF 09 tasting.  Gold/orange, lasting beige head.  Tripel Belgian.  Really good.  Rather good bit sweet but good tangerine fruit.  Lovely tripel.  Good balancing hop on finish.  Lovely.

Pours a hazy dark golden orange with golden peach hues when held to a light source and a one finger frothy, soapy white head that has very good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap and ring. Visible yeat even though its the fist 33cl pours of a 750ml bottle and visible carbonation bubbling up.

Earthy, slightly tart(read: not sour/wild) aroma with a bit of estery golden fruit from the Belgian yeast strain as well as some ripe banana, bread and subtle grassy malt character.

Soft carbonation up front that tickles the tongue with a heavy yeast medium body. Lots of earthy funk that again is not sour or acidic. Lots of estery light golden fruit, especially apple, pear and most prominent, banana. Nice peppery spice with a bit of zesty corriander that is slightly countered by a subtle malt backbone. The spice is very prominent up front and lingers throughout over the other flavors into a long dry finish which is slightly bitter. The alcohol is evident in the flavor but their is no warmth whatsoever, making this one dangerously drinkable. A bit to heavy on the spicy side but has a nice full body and complex flavor.

700th United States Rating: 750ml corked and caged bottle (Batch T9114) served in a Livery trappist glass.  Attractive glowing orange pour with a one-finger thick head of creamy beige foam that showed some good retention.  Nice clingy lacing.  The aroma included honey, orange peel, banana, sweet pale malts, and light candi sugar.  The flavor had strong fruity yeast esters, dried orange peel, honey, graham crackers, and some peppery spice.  Warming, but not overly alcoholic.  Medium-bodied mouthfeel.  Softly carbonated.  A solid example of the style.

GLASS: Tripel Karmeliet Goblet 
TEMP: Cellared at approx. 50 degrees 

After removing the the cage, the cork is removed with a loud, satisfying pop. The mist-like vapors coming from the bottle send the scent of honey and malt up to my nose, briefly.

The pour results in quite an impressive head. Thick creamy white foam that stands on its own for a good 60 - 75 seconds. When it finally settles, Im left with a liquid that is an amber color, not unlike a beautiful sunset.

Pulling the glass close to my nose, I smell honey, pepper, citrus, malt, and floral. Quite alot happening in the nose.

Tasting it is worth the wait. Once again the honey notes come to the forefront. They are joined by peaches and oranges mingling with maltiness, a bit of hops buried down a level or two, and a very nice pepperiness.

The nice thing about Tripels, in general, is the way they feel in your mouth. The liquid has what seems like thousands of tiny little bubbles and in each mouthful it seems that hundreds of these bubbles get into every space of your mouth.
This results in a wonderfully creamy sensation when drinking one.

Overall, this is a great example of what an American made Tripel can be.

Thanks Mark, pours hazy deep orange grapefruit with white head. The aroma is pretty full with apricots, apple, some modest spices and mild yeasty notes. The taste is crisp and almost bright with carbonation moving into yeasty spicy apricot, plum and apple notes. It even out midway then picks up a mild level of tannin fruit skin like tartness into the finish.

750 ml. Hazy deep gold body. Big, frothy white head, slowly diminishing. Aroma of toasted grain, bread, herbs, flowers, clove with notes of pepper, lemon with a hint of plastic. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly sweet, moderately bitter and moderately acidic. Medium to full body, velvely texture and lively carbonation. Alcohol comes through in the finish. Spicy, peppery flavors blend nicely with the sweetness that turns bitter in the finish. Wonderful balance with nothing being overly aggressive. The flavor outshines the aroma, but both are good. An outstanding tripel.

Thanks Tampa Tasting Group for the share.  Pours hazy yellow with an off-white head.  Nose is apple, caramel, yeast, honey, light fruit, and malt.  Flavor is very similar with lots of sweet apple, pepper, and fruitiness.  Solid medium-bodied tripel.
Very big head lasts and lasts. Amber. Big alcohol nose. Light delicate caramel.

sample from the bottle at Dr. Bills Tasting at Falling Rock during GABF on 9/26/09... deep orange pour... sweet and light over the mouth... medium body... deep spice notes with some banana.  really nice tripel.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 pours a dark golden colour very cloudy with a thin head which dissipates  quickly orange peel aroma and very light smooth taste easy on the palate no alcohol notes. 
great beer.
dark golden pour with a ton of creamy white head. nice malty aroma mixed with some sweetness and nuttyness. smooth mouth feel with a slight sweetness on the finish. delicious.

Bottle.  Poured a hazy golden color with a tall white fizzy head.  Nose is malty with fruity notes, spice, and Belgian yeast.  Medium bodied, somewhat oily mouth feel and decent carbonation.  Flavor is moderately sweet with caramel, citrus, peach, spice, yeast, and hops bitterness.  Finishes slightly sweet and spicy.

Pours a fizzy orange. Nose is spicy, cloves, sweet malts, candy sugar, sweet fruits. Flavor is a real nice crisp sweet malt, spicy yeast, cinnamon, cloves, mild banana, candy, bubblegum and ripe fruits. Maybe one of the best trippels i have ever had.
[750ml bottle] Really a very good beer. A little bit more than average carbonation. Color is a pretty yellow, and the head is medium and lasting. Very good beer.

Big thanks to fly!! Towering, dense, faintly-yellow head, leaving lace over orangeish golden beer, well-carbonated, hazed. Bit milky nose, smelling of sweet, sugary fruit (citrus mainly) and light cheesy twang. Sweetish, solvent-rich tripel, bit spicy, estery. Less fruity and sweet than the nose. Point of citrus all the same; banana warming up. Carbonation is very obvious, attenuation might well improve with aging. Rather well-bodied for a tripel, very slick to oily. Certainly not bad. I have no idea about the age/ripening of this beer, so I wonder if some raters tried this beer a tad to soon (young).  Steven, please dont tell me that youre responsible for the drivel under the "commercial description", second alinea, no?

Bottle: Hazy golden pour with a white film of head. Honeyish graham cracker aroma- has some rotted pear esters as well. Fluffy body with a flavor similar to the aroma. Old sweet pears and honey notes. Definitely a typically sweet and under attenuated American Tripel.

750 ml bottle.  One of the many flavors present here is banana.  Many more unidentifiable flavors.  Has a bitter, somewhat watery aftertaste.  Though it tries hard to be as Belgian as possible, it doesnt quite reach those heights.
750 bottle- FIRST DRINK- Nice belgian style beer, golden color, mellow flavor, you can hardly taste the alcohol at 9 percent. LAST DRINK-  Very sweet, finishes well.

Being a Dead fan, the title caught my eye, and I had to try it. Orangish-amber pour with a nice heady foam. Sweet aroma, fruity, belgian malts, very nice. The flavor is sweet, spicy, fruity, a nice flavorful mouth experience.

750 mL bottle (batch number T8088) from South Bay Drugs ($6.99).  Pours a hazy honey amber color.  The three fingers of white foam quickly dissipate to a thin layer.  Mostly sweet aroma of malts and especially fruit (banana, apple, pear) along with some yeastiness and light spice.  Flavor is really everything thats found in the nose, though not quite as sweet as the nose would indicate.  Finish is on the dry side and has a small amount of bitterness.  Medium mouthfeel and highly carbonated with a nice tingling on the tongue.  Alcohol completely hidden; very drinkable.

Pours a fizzy, hazy gold, with a well-sustained head - inviting aroma of apricot, peach, wildflowers, honey, herbs, some light belgian yeast phenols - fairly creamy palate, especially considering the high carbonation - sweet, but not as much as most american-made tripels, and it is balanced by a strong herbal component that blasts through some initial fruity esters, leaving a semi-dry, spicy/peppery finish - some alcohol heat on the back, but just enough to create a warming sensation - some hop bitterness on the end compliments the floral character, and makes this tripel distinctly american - quite good.

Pours cloudy golden with a very impressive frothy white head that dies out relatively quickly leaving very little lacing.  Aroma is yeasty with barnyard funk.  Flavor is bready with plenty of spice and a sweet finish.  Nice warming alcohol though you cant really taste it.  Very enjoyable Tripel.  Ill buy this one again and again...

750 into an abbey glass.  I found this a little light, but clean and nice. Aroma is esters and sweet with head but warms to alcohol. Flavor is sweet esters with some bubblegum and a decent bitter kick with a touch of alcohol.

2008 Bottle - Pours a hazy orange with a large white head...aroma is lemon, spice and yeast dough...banana and pear...flavour is similar, sweet and malty on the front end, distinct resiny, burnt sugar bitterness in the end...alcohol is definitley noticable and Im so glad I decided to kill this bottle alone after a few others, I was just remarking on how I hadnt been piss drunk in a while...

Bottle.  Rating No. 100.  Pours a large, rocky, frothy, white head.  Head is clingy and patchy.  Deep, honey golden, bordering on light orange body.  Hazy with some chunky yeast particulate.  Aroma is dominated by bready wheat malt, some yeast dough, mild fruity esters, a touch of citrus, some clove, fresh cut countryside grass and hints of raisin.  Flavor contains all of the above plus some caramel undertones and some warming alcohol.  Average carbonation for the style, light-medium body, sweet up front finishes with a candi-sugar crispness.  Warming, slightly punchy alcohol avoids being too aggressive.  Overall a solid, tasty, easy drinking tripel.

Bottle, corked and caged.  Hazy golden pour with a an enormous, very long-lasting rocky/creamy beige head.  Sweet malty nose, really very inviting, some sugary vanilla and marshmallow, caramel with faint dark fruit and earthy coriander.  Golden sunshine flavor with an alcohol kick coming on late, but relatively few higher-order alcohols.  Sugary sweetness dries out a bit.  Smooth and creamy feel with a light-medium body.  Faint little esters, some pleasant peppery spice but its well-blended and doesnt fall out.  Light grassy notes and citrus seem much juicier, much fresher than is normal for the style.  Very good, classically-styled tripel.

Bottled. Poured a hazy orange with a rocky and large white head. Aroma is spicy, banana, bread, and alcohol. Flavor is banana, pepper, clove, honey and melon meshed in a pleasing way. Finishes dry and hot.

A hazy amber ale with a thin white head. A pleasant yeasty aroma with coriander, orange peels, and epsom salts. In mouth, a nice malt with ginger, coriander, and warming alcohol. Nice, rich and smooth. Bottle at Mondiale 2009.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of sweet fruits, melon, peppery spices, and yeast.  Flavor of spicy bready yeasts initially with sweet fruits (apple, pear) and tingling spices.  More spicy/yeasty than fruity.  Solid triple, very drinkable.
8/4/8/4/17 (4.1/5)

Bottle, thanks to tytoanderso, big ups in fact for this one. Aroma of spice, yeast, flowers, and most notably delectable marmalade and honey. Flavor keeps the honey coming with lots of citrus, increasing but still balanced spiciness, biscuity and bready malt, and more yeast. Comes back to the marmalade at the finish. A wealth of flavor, complex, balanced yet notably big and bold. Creamy yet pretty dry mouthfeel. Luscious.

From the keg at Logans Pre GABF Party, Denver 10/10/2007
Small white head. Golden coloured fruity banana aroma. Slightly hazy in appearance. Some bitterness in a crisp malt finish.
Bottle and Liquid Sunshine VI.  Thanks BillKismet!  Peppery yeasty aroma, golden with a strong white head.  Very dry peppery flavor, strong and intense going where few American tripels dare.

Bottle sampled on 2/07/08: Pours a transparent orange bronze with a stringy-lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet caramely biscuity malt and Belgian yeastiness.  Body starts fairly full and sweet with nice biscuity pale maltiness and some light fruity esters.  Pretty well balanced, authentic and should age well.

Dark honey color with thick white head. estery aroma of bananas, clove, apricot. Flavor of pale malt and honey. light dried fruits, and yeast. The fruitiness is subtle and nice, no alcohol prevalent. Finish is clovey and dry.
Yellow pour with floaters and a creamy white head.  Fruit, peach, honey, spice, clove, pepper, some alcohol, and banana.  Well done tripel.  Not hugely interesting though.
Poured yellow with a white head. Aroma of spice and some fruit. Light fruit flavor with a spice finish.

Orange-amber with very head that at first fills 2/3 of the glass. The first whiff is of summer mush, then out pour veins of honey-tipped clove cigarretes, richly developed phenols, esters, and white pepper. The flavor is no less splendid. Complex esters and phenols, though no detectable banana. Well cloaked cloviness, light white pepper, edges of Carribean spiced rum warm the gullet. Trace of clove cigarette and syrup on the finish. An out of this world, best-in-class, Tripel.

Pours golden orange with a massive head and medium lacing.  Aroma is sweet fruit, coriander, lemon, soil, some minty notes, and a touch of pepper.  Flavor is initially sweet, bubblegum, lemon, and all spice blend into warm rye notes, sweet honey, and a touch of alcohol.  Very well done, not cloyingly sweet on the end like other Tripels Ive had.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2009 Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a very nice looking cloudy orange with thick fizzy off-white head. Aroma of some farmhouse, alcohol, fruit, spices. Flavor is nice, some farmhouse, alcohol, wheat, coriander, various spices, also detected a little honey, earthy, pepper. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with high fizzy carbonation. Overall, a very good beer....

750ml bottle.  Pours cloudy golden with a thin white head that quickly diminishes, quite fizzy. Nose is honey floral wheat and coriander, orange flower. Mildly spicy, yeasty flavor in which yeast and banana predominates. Rather alcoholic. Chalky but pleasant mouth feel.

Hazy amber pour with a huge white head.  Tons of carbonation in here.

Lots of banana and other fruity esters in the nose.  The body initially is over-carbonated, but some swirling helps fix that.  Subtle light fruits are in the taste...leaning towards tropical...with a touch of toffee.  Light on the tongue; very nice to see in an American tripel as too many end up too heavy.

Mouthfeel, as mentioned above, is initially too carbonated, but settles down to a nice, "light on the tongue" level.  

Recommended.

pours a semi-cloudy orange with a very large off-white head, and some lacing.

smell is not to strong, yeast, slight fruit, and a bit of pear.

taste is carbonated, fruit, sour malt, ends dry and slightly bitter.
Great belgian! slightly sweet - cloudy in appearance with a thin white head. Lovely fruity esthers.

Source:  750 mL bottle purchased at Frugal MacDoogals. Glass: Poured into my Orval Glass. Appearance: Poured a hazy golden orange color with a huge, bubbly white head.  Aroma:  Floral, with sweet malts.  A touch of alcohol on the nose, with spices. Flavor: Sweet malt, spices and a fruity finish.  Almost like applesauce. Palate:  Medium/full body with solid carbonation and a silky mouthfeel.Overall:  Wasnt disappointed.  Probably wouldnt buy again, but definitely a good representation of the style.

Reviewed 4/26/2009 (Bottle Batch number T8249):

Pours a huge foamy whitish colored head, bubbles, but diminishing somewhat. Very floral aroma, dusty. Sweet and strong. Very perfumy. Sickly sweet smelling. Light soft taste. Some carbonation. Very floral taste. Light fruit, like pear or apple. Some malty skunk present too, but very light. Pretty tasty.

750 ml bottle at the Bayou. This was the beer I shouldnt have had, man I got drunk that night. Anyway, pours a cloudy orange color with a thick white head. Lots of yeast, malts and some spices in the nose. Alcohol as well. The flavor was decent; smooth malts, spices, pepper, light fruit, apples and a warm alcohol presence. Pretty nice.

Golden in color with a taller off-white head. Decent lace. Aromas of Light fruit, lightly toasted malt and dough, floral scents, hint of coriander and alcohol. Full sweet flavors with light caramel, honey, raisins, resin and alcohol. Finish has a bit of burn and once again some alcohol. A nice dry malt flavor in the linger. This seems quite hot and lacks the subtleties I like in my type of tripel. I keep thinking this is just another strong golden. Perhaps Im a little let down after the Saison, but Ive been trying this over the last 1/2 hour and I am not catching much difference.

Clear pour, giant head, good lace, rising bubbles. Cinnamon spicy aroma. Lots of cinnamon with a strange alcoholic, almost medicinal aftertaste. These is definitely some camphor flavor, maybe this is old. Not bad but Ive been saving this tasting and am pretty disappointed.
Batch T8067 in Dallas.  Nice, solid tripel. Very well balanced and some nice spice in the flavour.  Definitely follows the traditional Belgian style.
(batch t8088)rusty yellow body with a nice fuzzy white head.aroma is bananas esters,oranges,cloves,and belgian yeast.the flavor is much of the same with some caramel malt.pretty solid i guess.
Very cloudy, burnt orange in appearance.  Nose is subtle with yeast, light corriander, spice and fruit.  Flavor is light, fruity, and orange.  Middies at best.

Sweet fruity aroma, light peppery spice, clove, dust perhaps. Pours golden with good carbonation and a fizzy head. Sweet dusty with hints of pepper and clove, banana perhaps. Light bitter finish. Fizzy carb, nice drinker. Oh yeah... My 36th Tripel rating. What you know about that?

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy orange golden with a large frothy white head that lasts awhile leaving behind good sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a spicy clove and orange peel. The taste is a dry fruit with a bitter finish with the alcohol very present. A very good abbey tripel from Boulevard.

Color is a hazy orange yellow with good carbonation and a thick head.  Aroma is sweet with a fruity yeast scent.  Taste is fruity, spicy and faintly bitter.  Starting with a medium body it goes down fizzy and smooth.  Finish comes in with a banana yeast flavor then some spiciness, a faint dried fruit taste and a light bitterness.  In the after taste the fruit fades giving way to a slight citrus that lets the bitterness linger on awhile.  This is a excellent Triple.

Sourdough, liquorice lemony nose.  Creamy shaving cream head, some decent lacing, orange/gold color.  Tart peppery clove and orange peel sweetness, slightly hot.  High carbonation, bitter finish, slightly alcoholic.  Decent structure, seems green, Ill bet this will age very nicely.

750ml bottle $8.50. Clear yellow color, almsot no head. It smells like spiced apples. I guess this does taste like a tripel but its subtle and the alcohol is well hidden. The quad and the saison have been my favorite from this series so far but this was tasty.
